title: 105_s314
content: SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. The Act titled "Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998" requires executive agencies to submit annual lists of activities not inherently governmental in nature to the Office of Management and Budget by the end of the third quarter of each fiscal year. The list should include the fiscal year when the activity first appeared on the list. The Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998 mandates executive agencies to submit annual lists of non-inherently governmental activities to the Office of Management and Budget. The list must include the fiscal year of the activity's first appearance, the number of full-time employees needed, and the contact information of the responsible Federal Government employee. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget reviews the agency's list and consults with the agency head before finalizing it for the fiscal year. Management and Budget reviews executive agency's list for a fiscal year, consults with agency head, and makes list public. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget publishes a notice in the Federal Register when the list of executive agency changes is available to the public. Any changes to the list must be made public and transmitted to Congress promptly. Competition is required within a reasonable time after the date. The head of the executive agency must use a competitive process to select a private sector source for activities on the list published in the Federal Register. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will issue guidance for the administration of contracting with a private sector source for executive agency activities based on cost comparisons. The executive agency must consider all costs, including quality assurance, technical monitoring, liability insurance, retirement benefits, and overhead costs, when contracting with a private sector source for activities. SEC. 3. CHALLENGES TO THE LIST. An interested party can challenge the omission or inclusion of an activity on a published list. Interested party refers to a private sector source with a direct economic interest in performing the activity. An interested party with a direct economic interest in performing the activity can challenge its omission or inclusion on a published list. This includes private sector sources, business associations, executive agency offerors, and labor organizations. An interested party with a direct economic interest can challenge its omission or inclusion on a published list within 30 days of the notice. The executive agency must decide on the challenge within 28 days. An interested party can challenge its omission or inclusion on a published list within 30 days. Within 28 days of receiving the challenge, an official must decide and notify the party with the rationale. The party can appeal to the head of the agency within 10 days of receiving the decision. An official must decide on a challenge to inclusion on a list within 28 days and notify the party with the rationale. The party can appeal to the head of the agency within 10 days of receiving the decision. SEC. 4. APPLICABILITY. This Act applies to executive agencies including executive departments, military departments, and independent establishments, as defined in title 5 of the United States Code. Exceptions include the General Accounting Office and Government corporations. The Act applies to executive agencies, including departments and establishments as defined in title 5 of the United States Code. It excludes the General Accounting Office, Government corporations, and certain depot-level maintenance and repair activities of the Department of Defense. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "Federal Government source" refers to any organization within an executive agency that uses Federal Government employees to perform an activity. An "inherently governmental function" is a function that is so closely related to the public interest that it requires performance by Federal Government employees. Government employees perform activities that require discretion and value judgments for the Federal Government, including monetary transactions and entitlements. Inherently governmental functions involve interpreting and executing US laws to bind the government to certain actions. The curr_chunk states that actions taken by the United States can bind the country to certain obligations, protect its interests through various means, impact private individuals' rights, and involve the management of government officers and employees. The curr_chunk defines the term "functions" as actions that involve controlling officers or employees of the United States, exerting control over government property, and managing federal funds. It excludes activities like providing advice or recommendations to government officials. The curr_chunk specifies functions that involve providing advice or recommendations to Federal Government officials, or performing ministerial and internal tasks such as building security, mail operations, and facilities maintenance. The Act specified various functions, including advising government officials and handling internal tasks. It will be effective on October 1, 1998.
